## Objective

The ultimate aim of my PhD research is to investigate emergence of *"landscape of dispersal"* across the region. In this presentation I will:

1.  attempt to describe the **pattern** of change quantitatively using centralization indices.

2.  explore potential of Ideal Free Distribution models to understand the **process.**

## Methods: Settlement Ecology

**Human Behavioral Ecology -- Ideal Distribution Models**

• **Ideal Free Distribution** (IFD) -- makes assumption of unconstrained movement into habitats of highest suitability that will decline with rising population density.

• **Ideal Free Distribution with Allee effect (IFDA)** -- incentivize cooperation and investments in landscape (e.g. irrigation) to increase habitats suitability but in time population pressure is leading to degradation and habitat depletion .

• **Ideal Despotic Distribution (IDD)** -- the access to habitats of individuals is controlled by other settlers. **IDD negative** -- despots defended access to high ranked habitats forcing settlers to occupy habitats with lower rank. **IDD positive** - despots allow to occupy their high ranked habitats in return for share in harvest (e.g.serfdom dynamics)
